abstract: Olympic curling competition has captivated Wall Street thanks to CNBC, which switches to curling coverage after the closing bell.
snippet: Olympic curling competition has captivated Wall Street thanks to CNBC, which switches to curling coverage after the closing bell.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street trading is often described as a blood sport. But inside the great investment houses, the sport of the moment is, of all things, curling — that oddball of the Olympics that is sort of like shuffleboard on ice.

headline.main: On Wall Street, Romancing the (Curling) Stone

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Bank of New York Mellon Corp

abstract: As he flirts with a challenge to Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the Democratic primary, Harold E. Ford Jr., the former congressman from Tennessee, has been dogged by questions about his compensation at Merrill Lynch, which, The New York Times reports, was at least $2 million annually.
snippet: As he flirts with a challenge to Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the Democratic primary, Harold E. Ford Jr., the former congressman from Tennessee, has been dogged by questions about his compensation at Merrill Lynch, which, The New York Times re...
lead_paragraph: As he flirts with a challenge to Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the Democratic primary, Harold E. Ford Jr., the former congressman from Tennessee, has been dogged by questions about his compensation on Wall Street, a sensitive issue because of taxpayer-financed bailouts of big banks during the financial crisis.

headline.main: At Merrill Lynch, Harold Ford Received at Least $2 Million

abstract: Details are emerging of a proposed new financing package aimed at increasing the number of digital 3-D movies screens across the country.
snippet: Details are emerging of a proposed new financing package aimed at increasing the number of digital 3-D movies screens across the country.
lead_paragraph: Details of a prospective financing package for the deployment of 14,000 new digital theater screens are beginning to emerge. The long anticipated build-up by the Digital Cinema Implementation Partners — a consortium operated by the AMC, Cinemark and Regal theater chains — will allow theaters to increase the number of 3-D screens beyond the 5,100 total that has been projected by this year’s end.

headline.main: Financing Package Takes Shape for More 3-D Screens

abstract: Bank of America Merrill Lynch said on Friday that it had hired a veteran Lehman Brothers energy banker as the new head of its Houston investment banking office.
snippet: Bank of America Merrill Lynch said on Friday that it had hired a veteran Lehman Brothers energy banker as the new head of its Houston investment banking office.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America Merrill Lynch said on Friday that it had hired Oscar Brown, a veteran Lehman Brothers energy banker, as the new head of its Houston investment banking office.

headline.main: BofA Merrill Hires New Head of Houston Office

abstract: Bank of America’s 750-plus page annual financial statement reads in some ways more like a marketing piece instead of the dry legalese that most people expect from regulatory filings.
snippet: Bank of America’s 750-plus page annual financial statement reads in some ways more like a marketing piece instead of the dry legalese that most people expect from regulatory filings.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who actually makes it through Bank of America‘s 750-plus page Form 10-K (including exhibits), filed earlier Friday, might be surprised by some of the language that the annual financial statement used to describe the bank. That’s because it reads more like a marketing piece or an advertisement instead of the dry legalese that most of us have come to expect from cumbersome Securities and Exchange Commission filings.

headline.main: A Bit of Boasting in Bank of America’s Filing

abstract: Updated: Bank of America’s ex-chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, received about $4.2 million for 2009, comprised largely of an appreciation in the value of his pension benefits, news reports said on Friday, citing a regulatory filing.
snippet: Updated: Bank of America’s ex-chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, received about $4.2 million for 2009, comprised largely of an appreciation in the value of his pension benefits, news reports said on Friday, citing a regulatory filing.
lead_paragraph: 4:34 p.m. | Update Bank of America‘s former chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, received about $4.2 million for 2009, comprised largely of an appreciation in the value of his pension benefits, news reports said on Friday, citing a regulatory filing.
